spans.text: I won't stay long at the entrance, because if I soak them for too long, the shellfish may not have time to spit out all the silt inside them. The two of them carried the purchased items into the kitchen and began preparing today's lunch.
Tomori, where do you keep the basins in your house?
Here. Taki, if you need anything else, just let me know.

Tomori handed over a small ceramic basin. Taki filled it with water and put the various patterned shells into the water. When she leaned over to rub the sand off the surface of the shells, her own face appeared in the water.
Along with the countdown above her head that was constantly decreasing.
(Damn it.)

She had been trying her best not to look in the mirror these past few days, but modern cities are never short of things that can reflect. Even if she hid in the kitchen, which had no mirrors, the surface of the water was still reminding her of the predicament she was facing.
When she realized that her heartbeat was gradually returning to zero, she had thought about how to make an appointment with Tomori, and how to explain the absurdity of her encounter to her.
But meeting her directly in the mall like this was completely beyond her expectations...
What's more, now she had ended up at Tomori's house by some twist of fate.
She turned her head to look at Tomori, who was cracking eggs into a bowl while softly humming a few MyGO lyrics. The broken phrases flowed with a joy that was as steady and continuous as water.
For a moment, she didn't know whether she should interrupt this joy.
She might die. Even if it was just a possible hypothesis, it immediately pushed her into the position of a breaker of the lifelong band promise.

The one who said she was willing to form a lifelong band with Tomori had become the first to break the promise. The thought of this possibility made her stomach curl up, and the burning sensation made her feel ashamed, and most of these emotions were directed at Tomori.
Tomori had the right to know about this.
(But where should I start?)
(Maybe I can start with a gentler topic.)
(I think I've been staying up too late recently... My body seems to be showing signs of sub-health. If it gets worse...)
But she still couldn't say it. There was no need to lie.
She had a feeling that Tomori would believe her even if she directly told her about the countdown.
Tomori was a writer, and a writer who had recently been writing fairy tales.
But what after she believes? This matter was as abrupt as the beginning of a Kafka novel, and there was no way to rationally deduce a solution.
She remembered the bewilderment she felt after searching for relevant information all night without success a few days ago. What state was she in now? What caused it? How to solve it?
(I don't know anything.)
(Even if I tell Tomori, can Tomori calmly accept it?)
Her behavior was just a prior announcement of her early departure, a traitor's request for forgiveness from the betrayed. Only she herself could be comforted.
(Tomori will definitely not sit idly by, but what can she do?)
The bitterness on the tip of her tongue made her sigh involuntarily, and a sense of powerlessness seized her.
(I can't let this feeling spread to Tomori, it's too cruel for her.)
(Maybe it's better to leave it as it is for now, and not tell Tomori about it.)
Rikki, have you been very tired lately?
I've been staying up a bit late recently, but it's okay.
That sigh just now didn't sound like ordinary fatigue.
It felt... very heavy.
(Is it that obvious?)
It's nothing, it's just that these are a bit difficult to wash.
She rinsed the shells in her hand in the water, and the countdown in the reflection was cut into tiny fragments by the shells.
But ingredients prepared with such care should taste better.
I'm looking forward to Tomori's cooking.
Rikki...
I know, it's here, right?
Tomori opened her mouth as if she wanted to say something, but Rikki had already squatted down and found Tomori's stew pot in the cupboard, and took it to the faucet to fill it with water.
Not this one.
Tomori's question was still coming.
(Not which one?)
She turned around, a strange intuition that Tomori had already discovered the core of the problem appeared, and the reasons for explaining her abnormality followed weakly: a cold, pollen allergy...
But Tomori's question clearly paused for a moment, like a car making a sharp turn.
This soup needs to be stir-fried first...
Tomori took the small pot and busied herself. Soon, only the crackling sound of frying onion granules remained in the kitchen.
(Did I get away with it...?)
(Tomori looks like she has something else to say.)
(...It's better not to ask.)
When the desire to express is suppressed by reason, emotions will be released in other forms.
The sound of the kitchen knife on the cutting board was continuous, and the dishes that the two had initially prepared quickly filled the dining table.
The cherry tomatoes are also cut, and will be used for cold salad later.
It feels like I'm running out of space...
The stew ingredients have all been put in, I'll take the rest to the table for now.
Rikki, is there any other dish you want to make? It should be enough for two people to eat.
Vegetables will release water when stir-fried, so they never look as much as they actually are.
(That's true, but there's already enough food prepared. Tomori could eat it for several days, so I should probably stop.)
Let's make stir-fried green peppers and potatoes. Does Tomori have a peeler at home?
Are you talking about a special peeler? I think I bought one, let me see if I can find it.

Tomori took a few steps towards the pot and squeezed the cream into the stewed soup that had been cooking for a while, then left the kitchen. Now only Rikki and a pile of green peppers and potatoes remained.
As if relieved, Rikki's shoulders slumped.
Sigh.
Rikki picked up a green pepper and started preparing it.
(When did it all start?)

It all started with the strange feeling when I opened the door and entered the entrance hall. The strange temperature difference, the sudden fainting, the inexplicable dream, and the countdown hanging above her head, approaching zero second by second.
She had been thrown off balance since she left the sink, like a child who had just lost her scooter and was walking softly towards her first fall.
This kind of panic about the unknown would definitely make her suffer later. The facts that have been confirmed will not scare her, but she is still a little absent-minded now.
The reason is simple - why hasn't that fall come yet?
Or maybe it was earlier than that? It's just that she didn't notice.

The dark circles under her eyes that appear from time to time, the daily headaches... Could those things that look like health warnings actually be the prelude to another disaster she can't understand?
She also thought that all of this was just a physiological reaction caused by long-term fatigue, but the obviously illogical phenomenon of decreasing heartbeat overturned this guess.
The black cat in the dream that told her that her days were numbered, and the impression of the cat she met when she went home one night overlapped.
Are there really talking black cats in reality?

Taki Shiina closed her eyes. She had the experience of accidentally splashing chili seeds into her eyes when she used too much force. It's more convenient to pull the head of the green pepper out with force instead of pressing it in.
But the thoughts that had been bothering her in her heart still had inertia, and the force of this press couldn't be stopped, and a big opening was cut in the green pepper in her hand.
(I should be more focused...)
Taki Shiina tried to pull the problem out of her head like chili seeds. She shouldn't be thinking wildly after making a decision. But at this moment, it was quiet all around.
She shook her head and picked up a potato. The slightly green dents were still staring at her like eyes.
Ugh... It doesn't feel good to look at it, so I should get rid of it quickly.
Tomori?
Coming! I'm still looking...
The response came from deep inside the room, weakened by layers of walls, as if from afar.
Of course Rikki wouldn't urge her. She returned to the cutting board and examined the ingredients she had prepared.
(What else needs to be done?)
She looked at the bowl of bubbling egg mixture.
(Did I add salt just now?)

She picked up the egg mixture and naturally began to stir it with chopsticks. The thick omelet that would be fried later didn't need this process to provide bubbles. This was just a way to relieve stress in the kitchen.

The chopsticks made a regular tapping sound when they collided with the porcelain bowl. Drummers are always more sensitive to rhythm. This was a tempo of 120 beats per minute. She slowed it down a bit, 100 beats per minute. Slower, 60 beats per minute.
The soreness brought about by busyness gradually reduced the speed, but it still maintained a familiar sense of rhythm. The sound of knocking echoed in the empty kitchen.
Tap—tap—tap
(It's the speed of the second hand.)

She stopped what she was doing, but the sound didn't stop. The second hand, like the Sword of Damocles, was always ticking above her head, now gained its own sound effect, swaggering and showing off in Taki Shiina's ears.
(I went out with the idea of saving time, but I wasted a whole morning here with Tomori.)
(Of course, being with Tomori is not wasting time, but...)
It had been several days since she first saw the countdown.
(Everything is still clueless, and the progress of composing is not ideal...)
(What should I do?)

After graduating from university, band rehearsals always ended with "Let's get together again next time if we have the chance", and began with the few people checking their schedules. This enthusiasm for seriously carrying out social niceties had once made her feel incredible.
"There will always be time, after all, we're a lifelong band."
Tomori had said that.

This composure and firmness were all based on the premise that a lifetime is very long - since we will be playing drums even when we become grandmothers, of course we won't mind one or two times when we are young.
(But now I've become the one who broke the promise...)
(Let's have a good meal with Tomori first... There may not be another chance like this.)
Forget about that string of numbers that will eventually return to zero. Everyone will die eventually, and it's most important to seize the time to leave something behind.
The sheet music that should have flowed like water was indeed stuck halfway, but creation is not guided by inspiration... not entirely.
There may be a usable passage in the middle of endless drafts. Pearls of inspiration are not only obtained through accidental picking up, but also require painful grinding.
(Should I go home and think about it now...)
Almost as soon as this thought appeared, Taki Shiina denied herself.
(What are you talking about, how could you have such a thought!)
(I must be possessed by a ghost... Let's have a meal with Tomori first and then consider the composition.)
Thoughts kept popping up in her mind, and she tried hard to suppress herself and not think about those negative questions.

The egg mixture in her hand wouldn't kindly season itself because of her current predicament. The question of whether salt was added to the egg mixture was still in front of her, and she had to try it herself to know.
Ugh... Pui.
There wasn't a trace of saltiness in the fishy smell of the raw egg. At least half of the problem was solved now.
It's boring to be idle here. Before Tomori comes back, I'll season the egg mixture first and make the tamagoyaki.
Where is the salt in Tomori's house...?
There was a small wooden glass bottle on the table. She picked it up and shook it gently, the white particles rubbing and rattling.
(Although I'm not a cooking novice, I always doubt that I'll mistake salt for MSG.)
(Am I too insecure?)
Taki Shiina twisted open the bottle and sniffed the mouth of the bottle gently. A pungent smell drilled into her nose, something other than the two - white pepper powder.
What a jackpot.
If you put this in, how strange would it taste?
The false alarm made the whole search process more serious, and one jar after another rose and fell in her hands.
When it came to a small blue porcelain jar close to the wall, a strange feeling came from her hand.
She turned the porcelain jar, and there was a piece of transparent tape on the side close to the wall, with Tomori Takamatsu's handwriting on the paper underneath - Salt
Pfft.

It seemed that she wasn't the only one who worried about putting the wrong seasoning. This kind of self-doubt always made Rikki worry about embarrassing herself, but Tomori also had this kind of thought, and her hanging heart would relax instead.
It feels very homey...
The negative thoughts in her mind were swept away by this simple little detail. She relaxed and devoted herself wholeheartedly to the dishes in front of her.
This little spoonful should be enough, let's start cooking.
Set up the pot, light the fire. As the first person in the band to start living alone, this action has become as skilled as an instinct.
It will take some time for the pot to heat up. She turned around to get the oil for the tamagoyaki.

The egg mixture in her hand wouldn't kindly season itself because of her current predicament. The question of whether salt was added to the egg mixture was still in front of her, and she had to try it herself to know.
Ugh... Pui.
There wasn't a trace of saltiness in the fishy smell of the raw egg. At least half of the problem was solved now.
The conclusion she had just drawn urged her to speed up the process. She would make the tamagoyaki before Tomori came back.
Salt jar? Is it this one?
She picked up a glass bottle with a wooden lid and shook it gently, the white particles rubbing and rattling. Taki Shiina carefully shook them into the egg mixture according to the amount.
(Add a small spoonful, and then stir it.)
An unexpected scene appeared.
Those crystals - or what are now confirmed to be plant debris - did not melt and disappear as Rikki had expected, but sank into the egg mixture and then floated up again.
She picked up the bottle just now and looked at it carefully.
Oh no, it's white pepper powder... Should I pour it out?
She picked up the egg mixture, and the heavy weight made her hesitate.
The negative thoughts in her mind were interrupted by the stumbling block that suddenly appeared in front of her. She sighed and began to think about a solution.
(Actually, if I put it in according to the amount of salt, it shouldn't be too much, and it shouldn't affect the taste too much.)
(Why not make it into egg drop soup? Pepper powder should be good in soup, and it can also enhance the flavor.)
Sigh... I can only do this for now.
Set up the pot and light the fire. As the first person in MyGO!!!!! to start living alone, she would actually make such a basic mistake.
Thoughts of self-blame surged into her heart. She turned around to get the water for the soup.
Rikki?
Ugh!

Tomori didn't know when she appeared behind her, holding a small kitchen knife in her hand. The result of suddenly relaxing after being tense for a few days was like this - she was startled by Tomori's appearance.
Tomori, when did you get back?
Just now, when Rikki was focusing on making lunch...
I searched the room but couldn't find the peeler, so I'll just use a knife to peel it.
Tomori, I'll do it. Be careful not to cut your hand.
She took the kitchen knife from Tomori's hand, picked up a potato, and slid the blade under its skin with her finger, rotating it and peeling off a long strip of skin.
Tomori walked to the side of the pot and poured the cleaned shellfish into the pot.
Next, just wait for it to simmer slowly.
Oh, by the way, have you seen this, Rikki?
She twirled the end of the potato peel, pinched it up and turned it around in her hand, and a small brown peel flower bloomed from her palm.
When I helped my mother cook at home before, she would make such flowers for me.
Tomori straightened her body to get closer to her mother's height.
The most basic part of the pyramid of needs is the physiological need for eating, and such small flowers bloom at the foot of the pyramid.
Rikki has put in a lot of effort in the kitchen today, and she should also get a flower.
Tomori fixed the flower with a toothpick and handed it to Rikki, who was cutting the shredded potatoes.
Th-Ah... Thank you, Tomori.
I will cherish it.
(The pocket of the windbreaker is very big, so there shouldn't be any risk of squeezing it. I'll wrap it in paper and put it away.)
When she stopped to put away the potato peel flower, Tomori scooped up a spoonful of stew.
Rather than cherishing this flower, I hope Rikki can cherish herself first.
Rikki is obviously very good at cooking, but what does she usually eat?
And buying so much food at once, Rikki must have something to do again, so she doesn't plan to eat properly.
Never mind, Rikki, try the taste first.
The gratitude of being cared for and the embarrassment of being told the truth were mixed together. Shiina Taki could no longer say anything to Tomori's helpless smile.

Tomori handed the bowl to the other party, and a creamy, savory aroma came from the cooked soup. The hunger caused by a morning of busyness was appropriately awakened. Shiina Taki tasted a small mouthful along the edge of the bowl.
Delicious.

She took another small spoonful with a small soup spoon. The fresh and sweet clam meat was accompanied by the warm and thick soup base. With one bite, it seemed that the fatigue of the past few days was relieved, and she couldn't help but let out a long sigh of relief.
No chef would refuse to let his diners show such an expression. Tomori scooped up another spoonful, as if she wanted to feed the other party with this dish.
Eat more. Rikki always seems to be worrying about others.

When she was in school, she worried about the band, and after her internship, she had more children to worry about; when she graduated and moved out to live alone, she was still worrying about whether I could cook.
She put the cooked creamy clam chowder into a bowl.
The band has long passed the most difficult start-up stage.
The little girl in the photo you shared seems to have found the joy of drumming recently.
The last answer has also been plated and is being taken to the dining table by Tomori. Her voice came from the living room.
Everyone is working hard to move forward.
Rikki, can you relax and worry more about yourself?
Come and eat.
Her face seemed to be on fire, and her eyes were surrounded by a warm current. Shiina Taki lowered her head, and her watery long hair covered her flushed ears along the gravity.
Yeah, I'll finish this dish and come.

The water on the pot was bubbling, and Rikki used chopsticks to spread the kelp in the water. When she picked up the egg mixture, she looked at the bowl again worriedly. Most of the white pepper powder had sunk to the bottom of the bowl.
(It should be fine... right.)
She poured the egg mixture into the water, and the golden egg flowers swirled along the direction of the water flow stirred by the chopsticks.
Then it's salt.
(I can't get it wrong this time.)
She found the correct salt jar, shook two small spoonfuls of salt into the soup, and then stirred it.
(The soup can be taken out of the pot after the salt is completely dissolved.)
She stared at the vortex caused by the stirring in the middle of the pot, counting the seconds silently in her heart.
One.
(Is the bottom of the vortex sucking the egg flowers and kelp in, or is my hand bringing the egg flowers and kelp out of the vortex?)
Two.
(If a person is caught in such a vortex...)
Three.
(What am I thinking?)
She felt that her body seemed to be leaning to the right. When she wanted to lean to the left a little, her hand directly supported the counter.
The electric stove that had just finished cooking the creamy clam chowder still had residual heat, and she withdrew her hand in pain.
(No way...)
The rotating part seemed to have ended, but the ground had not yet solidified. The dizziness entered a familiar stage.
(Not at this time!)
The pot had been heated to the appropriate temperature. Rikki brushed a layer of oil on the bottom of the pot with a brush, poured in the egg mixture, shook it, and rolled up the solidified egg skin.
Brush oil, pour in egg mixture, shake, roll up solidified egg skin. The making process of tamagoyaki needs to repeat this process over and over again.
She used a wooden spatula to push the egg skin upward. It seemed that she didn't brush enough oil, and the egg skin stuck to the bottom of the pot.
Brush oil, pour in egg mixture, shake, roll up solidified egg skin.
Don't rush!
She cursed in a low voice, and realized that she had said her thoughts out loud when she heard the sound.
(What am I panicking about?!)
Her breathing became more and more rapid, and the sound of her heartbeat was as loud as if it was right next to her ear.
She suddenly had a feeling that she was not meeting this inexplicable panic for the first time.
(Not at this time!)
She turned off the stove, and in front of Tomori, who was setting the table, she rushed into the bathroom.
